Award.AwardTitle: Synthetic and Mechanistic Investigations of CO-releasing Divalent Metal Acireductone and Flavonolate Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Inorganic, Bioinorganic and Organometallic Chemistry Program supports Professor Lisa M. Berreau of Utah State University (USU) for the preparation and characterization of divalent metal acireductone and flavonolate complexes. Carbon monoxide (CO) has recently been implied in smooth muscle relaxation and may be involved in triggering (or inhibiting) apoptosis. The mechanistic pathways of the CO-release that occur upon treatment of these complexes with oxygen are elucidated. The understanding of CO regulation and production may give insight into links between metal homeostasis and other regulatory mechanisms in biology. This work investigates the structure, stability and reactivity of C1(H)-substituted acireductone complexes with Ni(II) chelated by multidentate pyridine-based ligands and clarifies the role of single electron transfer and radical chemistry in the oxidation of a metal-coordinated acireductone. An understanding of the role of the metal ion identity in directing the regiochemistry of the acireductone oxidation is also being developed.

Graduate, undergraduate and high school students participate in the research. The activities of the ACS Student Affiliate Group at USU bring students in contact with the elementary, middle and high school students in the local area. Professor Berreau and her group prepare hands-on chromatography experiments that are made available to middle school science teachers in Logan, Utah. Two students from a local charter high school are hosted in the laboratory each summer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to prepare, characterize, and examine the reactivity of synthetic metal complexes that exhibit carbon monoxide (CO) release reactivity from coordinated biologically relevant organic molecules, specifically acireductones and flavonols. These metal complexes were designed to have structural and functional relevance to metalloenzymes that catalyze biological CO-release reactions. Our approach involved examining the details of the CO-release reactions so as to understand how naturally occurring molecules (acireductones or flavonols) might be used as next generation CO-releasing molecules (CORMs). This area of research is of significant current interest as CO has been identified as a signaling agent in biological systems (including humans) and the controlled introduction of CO has been shown to lead to positive health effects including anti-inflammatory and antiapoptotic effects, and smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Based on these properties, there is currently strong interest in the development of new CORMs for possible therapeutic applications.

Our studies of acireductone-containing complexes centered on understanding how differences in the nature of a metal ion bound to the acireductone, as well as the surrounding organic ligands, influence the O2-dependent reactivity leading to CO release. Over the course of the project, we found that the presence of Ni(II) versus Fe(II) influenced which carbon-carbon bonds were cleaved and CO release reactivity. Specifically, we discovered that an Fe(II) acireductone complex, in the presence of water, underwent reaction wherein CO is not released from the acireductone. This type of reactivity was never encountered with Ni(II) acireductone complex analogs, which in all cases exhibited CO release upon reaction with O2. Only modest changes in the product distributions of CO-release reactions from Ni(II)-bound acireductones were identified when (1) the supporting ligands of the Ni(II) center were varied from hydrophobic to hydrophilic, and (2) when the protonation level of the acireductone was dianionic versus monoanionic. Notably, detailed mechanistic studies revealed that all reaction pathways leading to CO release in these acireductone-containing complexes involve the formation of a triketone intermediate, which subsequently undergoes oxidative carbon-carbon bond cleavage.

In the second portion of this project we investigated the chemistry of metal flavonolate species as CO release agents. Notably, we discovered oxygen-dependent, photoinduced CO release reactivity that is influenced by the nature of the metal center. This photochemistry is distinct from the isomerization reactivity exhibited by free flavonols, demonstrating that metal coordination of the flavonol enables clean CO-release reactivity.

In terms of broader impacts, this project involved both domestic and international collaborators. Five graduate students, seven undergraduates, two summer undergraduate internship participants, and a visiting scientist from China, all received training in multiple areas of chemistry, including inorganic, organic, and photochemistry. This team of researchers was comprised of ~50% women and one minority student. Results from the project have been disseminated through journal publications and presentations at local and national meetings.
